commentBody:
Here's the Wednesday puzzle!

Nice one, Freddie.
49 Across
I‚Äôm missing something‚Äîhow is 28D path? I got road (hesitating to put it in caps if I‚Äôm mistaken!). That said, I have the puzzle filled and still haven‚Äôt succeeded so something‚Äôs amiss‚Ä¶.
28D advice in 'tricky clues' is incorrect. Solution requires ROAD, not PATH :)
28D is the wrong answer in the wordplay column.
Deb will be pleased to see how many people are very carefully reading the column..
Would like to know how that mistake got into the column.  There must be a story.

Finished in 13:18. Slowed down by some flyspecking -- I had "NOt I" for 26d which left the headscratching "ACtE" for 32A.

Otherwise, fun quick solve. No rebus squares, so the usual Thursday complainers will have a bit less to grouse about! ü§™

I did find this one Thursday-appropriate, if a bit on the light side. I enjoyed the theme in hindsight. I didn't really get a quicker solve from the theme clues, though, since I easily filled the first three theme entries on the crossings.
Appreciating the picture of Jose Ramirez. The city of Cleveland just named a street after him. He's a living legend.
Fun. Like popcorn. Figuring out the trick helped. I always solve the hint first by working the clues around it. ‚ÄúALLTHUMBS‚Äù helped. 20+ minutes.

Cute, simple, probably better for a Tuesday.  I had "nothing tomo" (with roam) for a bit longer than I'd like to admit.

Nothing much more to say here.  I'd have liked to see more of the theme but perhaps there's not much else to do with it...

Nice little puzzle.

I had a good tussle with this puzzle. I wasn‚Äôt getting the theme (which turned out to be clever), until I got the revealer, which opened up the rest of the puzzle.  I did myself no favors by trying noti instead of NORI.  

The clue for DOHARM made me smile for some reason.
What a rude comment about poor old Jabba. He might be a perfectly healthy weight for his species.
I solved in my usual time without ever catching on to the gimmick. Ugh.
28 down is not PATH as noted in the blog! Reading that really sent me down an unnecessary review of that secrion

I have to admit, before I read any other comments, that this puzzler *really* gave me trouble.  In the end I got it, but it took forever and wasn't confident at all I would.

So many places I just didn't have a clue.  For example, I didn't know Soy beans were SOYA.

I've never heard of SEMTEX.  Not at all familiar with "Il Trovatore".  Never heard of CHER hair.

40A really bothers me.  It seems to clue a response *to* "Aw, Shucks", not something that occurs simultaneously with "Aw, Shucks".

I made multiple errors:  path before ROAD, OKay before OKOK, NOtI before NORI. breadED before DEBONED.

Sheesh, I really stunk at solving this one.  

An ugly gold star.

Hi all,

Thanks for reporting my good. The answer to 28D is ROAD, not PATH.

I've corrected it in the column.

I‚Äôm a bit on the fence about this one. I agree on the Thursday placement, while it doesn‚Äôt have the clever trick you might expect it‚Äôs too hard for a Wednesday‚Äîand it was hard for me, not in an unfair way, I had to jump around a bit. I was very intrigued by the theme as I was solving, I solved all the clues before the revealer and was thinking what could these have to do with each other? Once I got to the end I felt a little let down. I like how ‚Äútwo down‚Äù and ‚Äúone out‚Äù were sort of phrases in their own right‚Äî‚Äúone out‚Äù in baseball and ‚Äútwo down‚Äù (and one to go)‚Äîbut that doesn‚Äôt really follow with ‚Äútwo up‚Äù (maybe ahead two games?) and certainly not ‚Äútwo moving around each other‚Äù. Also I assume that is meant to be an image of ‚Äútwiddling one‚Äôs thumbs‚Äù but that‚Äôs not the image in my mind, I just think of moving thumbs separately‚Äîwhat do you all think?
I thought most of the clues were fine although nothing much leapt out at me, my favorite was the HOLMES quote and DOHARM was a gimme. Finally, I won‚Äôt reiterate again here but NORI is flat out wrong, see my earlier comment in a response for my reasoning.
Overall it solved like a themeless to me except for 3 long entries you had to work around and couldn‚Äôt guess. That had some enjoyment for me but no spark.

'Two up': ELAINEBENES

'Two up': THEFONZ
üëçüëç loved it! Just hard enough and fun to figure out the trick.

Tough puzzle, but it was a clever theme, and Thursdays aren't supposed to be Mondays. The Tricky Clues in the column, though - passing over that whole southwest corner like NOBRADAY and LEONORA are easy-peasy, and giving us a hint for THE. That was tough.

I had an early meeting this morning and missed my usual xword puzzle time.  Sat down after supper to catch up -- thought it was  really challenging for a Wednesday. . .not realizing y'all had already published tomorrow's puzzle.  But it's not even 11:00 on the east coast --what time do you post the daily puzzle?  I wish i'd thought to look at the date before I started he solve.  Alas, now my Thursday morning is a yawning void!!
How do I get my streak corrected?
Let‚Äôs all send some healing energy Dolly‚Äôs way. So much more than a BLONDE ‚Äî she‚Äôs a national treasure.  Get well soon, Dolly!

There were a couple of misdirects for me. 32A I tried elms, then firs, and then finally ACRE made itself known üòÖ 54A started as sOdAS before COLAS (HOLMES set me straight). And I stared at the revealer once I finished and still wasn‚Äôt getting it. Walked away for a few minutes and just picked it back up. ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Oh‚Ä¶I get it now. ALL THUMBS 
üëéüèºüëéüèº
üëçüèº
üëâüèºüëàüèº
üëçüèºüëçüèº

I am a geezer but not a fogy. 




Just sayin‚Äô.

I had the whole puzzle otherwise done for about 9 minutes before I corrected "NOT I" to "NOR I."  I knew that's where the error almost certainly was, but I just couldn't get past the obvious correctness of "NOT I."

Crosswords really force you to confront how easy it is to cling to a mistake, even when you know darn well that it's wrong.

This was a good one. Was a fun thing to do after the Yankees ended their season tonight. Solved the theme through the crosses. Then read Wordplay. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è  Loved the non-theme fill as well. Thanks, Freddie! Have a great Thursday, y‚Äôall.
Twice this week ape has been nouned, rather than verbed, in an NYT crossword. If this is the new policy, I like it.

On one thumb, I am happy that they clued APE in a non offensive way to apes for a change! 

On the other thumb, I'd have preferred NORI clued as it normally is to sushi. I know my thumb and I are not alone in that... Or probably in wondering too long what on earth ACtE is.

On a third thumb, who is CHEt and why was his hair so popular back in the day. Har!  It sounded very '70s to me and I hadn't particularly heard of Cher hair. I wore my hair more  like Scooby-Doo in the '70s. With clothing that looked like Laura Ingalls Wilder would have worn. 

My parents really should have been arrested for crimes against humanity. Wonder if there's a statute of limitations on that...? I have the photographic proof to hold my mom accountable.

And now, I'm all out of thumbs.... I'm so lost without them, I know they were right believing for so long. I'm all out of thumbs and have NOTHINGTODO... And I NEEDARIDE but I'm all out of thumbs. 

MAN, this comment is spiraling downhill at ULTRA sonic speeds. I'll see myself out!
Solved it without getting the theme! Nice one.
Very cool puzzle.

"Let's make the state capital Augusta."
"Works for ME!"

(Going there is the Maine event.)

when in order to get fill you have to physically twiddle your thumbs with a stupid grin on your face after futilely trying to rotate them around each other like tiny sausage heavenly bodies managing only half orbits you know youre standing in the shadow of a fine puzzle.
Dolly Parton was asked if she was bothered by "dumb blonde" jokes. She replied "No, because I know I'm not dumb... and I know I'm not blonde." :-)

Dolly Parton famously not dumb and not blonde 

Nice puzzle.

A very entertaining puzzle, with a few gimmes to point us in the right direction, but even so, I never knew quite where it was going. A lot of it was funny, and all of it had a tongue-in-cheek freshness. Most enjoyable.

Thumbs up, I'd say.  Thank you, Freddie, and I'm still GRINning.

This was an interesting experience. I got the theme quite quickly, but one of the themed entries had me confused. I may have heard the expression "Twiddling one's thumbs", but I'm really not sure I have, and I certainly didn't know what it meant. Thus, the entry stumped me. I had some problems with the crosses around there (for example, even though a GRAM is very familiar to me as our basic unit of weight, I know almost nothing about carats), but in the end they gave me the answer.

Having NOt I rather than NOR I required a lookup in the end. NOt I looked so obviously good I was not bothered by the weird ACtE, of which there are 300 on the National Mall. When I did not get my gold star, I went back to the mysterious spots, and the National Mall clue was the first one I googled. ACRE... Ok. Imperial units are just not something I ever think of, even if I know their names.

I have not heard of NO BRA DAY as a breast cancer awareness observance. It has no entry in Polish on Wikipedia. Breast cancer awareness is a huge thing over here though. Women are encouraged to get mammograms, and they can do so for free, not only at publicly funded healthcare facilities, but also at specially equipped, government-funded buses ("mammobus") that tour the country, getting to places where there may be no local doctor's office.

As long as we are extolling Dolly Parton, I wanted to point out as a pediatrician she is a strong reading advocate and founded the Imagination Library. I work at a community clinic and all our low income families can sign up and get free books monthly for all their kids from birth to age 5 . She really is a national treasure.
Fun theme. Not too hard, but still rewarding.

The emus ate my previous attempt 

Dolly famously isn‚Äôt one of the  BLONDES

She also owned the joke as she is also famously not ‚Ä¶

Rheas are better than emus

Contrary to the view expressed earlier by others, I think it is clear that NOR I is the opposite of "Me too".
Person 1 says, I was not sexually abused.
Person 2 says, I was not sexually abused.
Person 3 says,  "Not I"
Huh?
Person 3 would have to say, "Nor I"
I still use a Rolodex. Maybe for sentimental reasons.

Little Jack Horner called to say he was plum stuck on this theme for the longest time.

Me? I figured that, sooner or later, I'd find THUMBthing to thay about this.
[groaning with pleasure]

Do we all agree this felt like a Thursday puzzle?

Not I.

Felt like a Wednesday for me. Theme was fine, but very straightforward and neither wordplay nor a trick with format.

Oh well. Roll on, Sunday.

Mea culpa, I disliked 41D (Overshadows) and the answer (DWARFS).

Very non-PC in the Little People's community. I would have preferred ECLIPSES, but I had to put in what the puzzle wanted. Editors, please BOLO for things like this prior to letting the puzzles get published.
üëçüèºüëçüèº
Wednesday level fill and Wednesday level theme
Could not figure out for the life of me what 300 ACtEs on the National Mall could be üò¢

Such an enjoyable puzzle that I could find nothing opposable in it.







Et tu, emu.
Well, I for one felt pretty good when I caught on‚Äîthe difference between starting late at night and doing it first thing in the morning. As Siskel and Ebert would have said, üëçüëç

The top 7 rows of the puzzle were pretty straightforward for me, and I filled in both themers with crosses.  Then I didn't have much until I got to the revealer, which let me figure out the next two themers and let me finish up fairly quickly.

Oh, it's DEBONED!  I kept trying to figure out a 7 letter word for salmonella ridden.

I did spend a few seconds making fists with my THUMBS out and pointing towards each other and orbiting my THUMBS around each other before I realized I needed to interlace my fingers and twiddle instead.  I'm glad I was doing this puzzle at home and not in a public place.
The print version was better.
45D‚Ä¶ *chef‚Äôs kiss*

NO BRA DAY was news for me but apparently a thing

One of the VERY rare Thursday where I got the gag without having to look at the Blog post - which makes it a good day. 

Clever puzzle - enjoyed working it

S B M U H T Not an easy one for me, but finally catching on to the trick was a huge turning point and that's always a nice touch. Interesting puzzle find today - a Friday from March 25, 1994 by Harvey Estes. Don't recall seeing another one like this. A couple of theme clues and answers: "Fast planes from New York" JFKSSSTS "Erving's cars" DRJSBMWS And two other theme answers: WKRPSDJS NFLSMVPS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/25/1994&g=4&d=D ...

I got the first and second theme answers easily, and immediately thought of thumbs, no idea why. So I looked for the revealer and was happy that ALL THUMBS fit right in. But had a little trouble with NOTHING TO DO, because it's not exactly a phrase someone would say, even though the clue evoked twiddling my thumbs very simply. 

I thought this puzzle was totally lacking in challenge for a Thursday, but I'll bet I won't be saying that for Friday's after this easy walk in the park.

As for DO HARM, that's another expression that is unlikely to be used, unless it's describing the MO of one unnamed bald individual with soulless eyes whose cruelty knows no bounds.

Ok, I know I write too much.  But I have to tell you my thumb story.  I hope you'll stick with me, but I forgive you if you don't.

In math and physics, there is something called "the Right Hand Rule".  It involves something called the cross product of two vectors.  I know, I know, I said no math, but just bear with me.  

It involves the right hand.  You imagine using the fingers of your right hand to  mentally push one vector into another, and the direction of your answer is the way your thumb is pointing.  Again, just trust me.

So the Right Hand Rule is used to predict the direction of the cross product, and we can make that simple:  it's either up, or down, depending on which way the thumb of your right hand points. 

I had a physics problem which had the answer in the back of the book.  I got everything right about the problem except I had the direction wrong.  I thought it was "down", and the answer in the back of the book was "up".

I struggled for hours with that problem, bashing the door frame in my mother's house with my right fist as I often did in the testosterone fueled days of academic competition.

I finally realized my error.

I was using my left hand, because my pencil was in my right hand.

If you've read this far, congratulations.

A capital-R Riddle puzzle.  Where I‚Äôm hopelessly stymied as to why NO WAY JOSE is the answer to [Two down], not to mention the other theme clue/answers, and then finally I uncover the revealer and the heavens part.  (Hi, @Deb!)

Those are the best riddles.  The ones that get you good.

This puzzle was a fun, smart, and engaging.  Enough bite to satisfy my brain‚Äôs workout ethic.  Lovely misdirect for me in [Infantry arm].  Lovely wordplay in [Break the Hippocratic oath, say]. And something I‚Äôve never done before while solving a puzzle: maneuver my hands into various thumb-centric positions.

Then pure joy at remembering ‚Äútwiddle‚Äù, a Hall Of Fame word I haven‚Äôt thought about in ages.  Icing on the cake was the glorious PuzzPair¬© of APE and a backward KOKO.

Came into the box hoping for a day brightener and left it buoyant.  Bravo and thank you, Freddie.  I loved this!
I liked the theme, but for some reason nothing was clicking with me in this puzzle. Almost 12 minutes more than my average Thursday. Still, if they were all easy, it wouldn't be as fun.
I don't think THOU is Old English, unless you're just indicating that it's seldom used nowadays, and if that's the case, why capitalize "Old?"

At least the constructor agrees that this is not a Thursday puzzle!

That doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs a bad puzzle. In fact, I‚Äôd give it two thumbs up. But editors, please indulge us with our Thursday tricky treats. Some of us wait all week for them!

Nice childhood memories today, of the sweet smell of Mom‚Äôs freshly baked ginger-snaps, the anticipation waiting for them to cool enough, and the warm feeling of them in my hand just before the first bite after she finally said ‚ÄúEnable‚Äù.


Fun puzzle.

My daughter and her friends text really fast with two thumbs‚Ä¶

Somehow I can‚Äôt pick that method up‚Ä¶.  On a full keyboard I still 10-finger type as I learned in typing class in 1971‚Ä¶ but two-thumb typing on my phone something I‚Äôve never picked up.

My fingers are so large I have a 1 in 5 chance or so of hitting the neighboring letter‚Ä¶ often when filling the crossword when I mean to hit ‚Äúm‚Äù and I hit ‚Äúdelete‚Äù instead, and sometimes I end up on a strange spot on the puzzle.  That is when I use my right index finger alone and aim it carefully.  Typing with my two larger thumbs on a phone seems impossible.

Often when I flyspeck the puzzle in the final step the  problem is a wrong neighboring letter hit by my large finger that I overlooked.

Now that would be a challenging Thursday‚Ä¶ the trick being to need to enter the letter to one side on the tiny phone keyboard for the italic clues.

For today‚Ä¶.

‚ÄúTwo typing‚Äù

‚ÄúYOUTH TEXTING‚Äù

Short of time, so I failed to ponder sufficiently at 32A...and I had (in the spirit of The Little Red Hen) NOT I for 26D.
Shows me (again) that it's not good to race through a puzzle.
I didn't realize LOKI was Thor's brother; obviously, the younger brother seeking a niche and some attention...

Always love being reminded of the Basel Kunstmuseum courtyard!  
Very much wanted TWIDDLING in the puzzle.  Freddie, please take this under advisement for your next puzzle.  Ah, well.  One can't have everything.

Very solid Wednesday puzzle, verging on a themed Friday. But definitely running on the wrong day.

Can only assume that the editors are currently short on Thursday-esque puzzles.

Don't think I'm familiar with the gesture described for NOTHINGTODO. The rest were easy enough to figure out once I got ALLTHUMBS.

Will abashedly admit that my first entry for "I am a brain ‚Ä¶. The rest of me is a mere appendix" was HAMLET. Followed by HALxxx from 2001: A Space Odyssey. Fortunately I righted the ship and was able to salvage today's journey.

That is not what cookies do.
Cookies are trackers stored on your computer that can help a webpage function or keep track of what you like/dislike

Kudos to those solvers who could fill the themers from the crosses without catching the overall direction.  I needed to dive down to the reveal's friendly clue to figure out what was going on.  Managed to come up for air after that.  

I did stumble at the ACtE/NOtI cross but manage to get out of the weeds there in the end.  Nice one and thanks.

Because I‚Äôm such an open-minded guy I‚Äôve been wracking my brain trying to think of a way to make NORI work despite my earlier arguments. Here‚Äôs the best I could come up with. IF you concede that METOO means ‚Äúboth of us are going‚Äù then NORI means ‚Äúboth of us aren‚Äôt going‚Äù. MAYBE that‚Äôs close enough for a crossword clue and I‚Äôll throw that out to the folks that are defending it. I still think it‚Äôs a very imprecise and poorly designed clue, since you would never use that as a stand alone statement and since NOTI is such a clearly better answer.

I solved 58A before any of the other themed clues and tried really hard to cram that into rebuses, to no avail. Being able to solve a Thursday without outside help is a big personal victory for me, so thanks, loved this puzzle!
Trust me. This is safe for work: https://www.facebook.com/groups/franksthefarside/posts/1725448914830549/

SEMTEX is unfortunately familiar to me because of it was in the news a lot during The Troubles in Ireland.

I just wasn't on the right wavelength for some of this. 
I didn't know what "Yeesh" meant to start with, or that "Aw shucks" linked to a GRIN, I couldn't figure out what the theme clues meant, even when I had all the letters. 

I haven't hitchhiked in 50 years so that didn't pop into my head, and I would have said I needed a lift, not a ride. Yes, I know the Beatles sang Ticket to Ride, but that was unusual!

I did remember ROLODEX from old American films. 

It was a clever theme of course, and nice to see NESSIE!
GRIN has me stumped. Who is grinning?

What an inspired and original idea!  What a huge "Aha Moment
 it gave me when I got to the revealer! Without the revealer, I wonder if anyone would get the theme?  Certainly I wouldn't have.  But then the scales fell from my eyes and everything fell into place.  

I never cease to be amazed at the inventive ideas constructors manage to come up with.  As I've said before, every time I think there's no new idea under the sun, someone proves me wrong.  This idea -- so simple, so smooth, so seemingly effortless -- seems absolutely genius to me.  I love this puzzle, Freddie!
The theme itself is cheesy like a Monday or Tuesday, but the clues themselves were definitely Thursday level!
Who didn't get the theme until after she completed the crossword? (Two back)!

Finished less than a minute more than my Thursday best - really felt like more of a Tuesday, with a cutesy theme. If I'd bested my best I'd have an asterisk on that time. Was lovely though! Sometimes a quick Thursday is just what a body needs.

Anyone here old enough to remember those Maidenform "I dreamed..." ads? The sins of Madison Ave., long before the NOBRADAYS https://share.google/mme0t2zXYFNoCZv84 They say the French have a word [phrase?] for it, and I think "ni moi non plus" wins for NOR_I... It's a LOKI way to make clear it supports of an already-expressed disagreement. Sorry for the re-hash. Just SOYA know: whenever I see SPRIG, I remember TJ who commented briefly on WordPlay decades ago. He allowed as how his paycheck had arrived graced with a SPRIG of parsley... His wages had been garnished. Still makes me smile. You can put THUMBtips together to make the bottom of a heart, but too complicated to bring in the two index fingers On The Other Hand--- Jerk one back over the shoulder: GET_OUTTA_HERE!! Have a lovely Thursday, all y;all!!

[Two to oneself]


I kinda regret letting my Hominidae membership lapse.






THIS GUY

I haven't watched "RoboCop" in a long time, but I don't remember an UZI having any prominence in that movie. You might as well clue (insert any car here) as "Car appearing in "Bullitt."" I do remember Paul Weller's character carrying a full-auto pistol.

"Terminator" would have been better in the clue, if only for the gun store scene:

Clerk: Anything else?
Terminator: Phased plasma rifle in the 40-watt range.
Clerk: Hey, just what you see, pal!
Terminator: The UZI nine millimeter.
Clerk: You know your weapons, buddy. Any one of these is ideal for home defense.
Perhaps not a typical Thursday puzzle, but left me feeling much better about myself than a usual Thursday, so I'll allow it. Had a lot of fun with this one!
Boring puzzle, bad cluing. Two down.

Second try

S_issy Hankshaw approves this puzzle.
And I so wanted "a certain leviathan" to be Carvel's F_udgIE the Whale.

I appreciated the advice to sit and think with the revealer. Usually I am trying to solve for speed (but not really for any good reason).
 
I came to Wordplay because I was getting really frustrated, but I immediately went back to the puzzle and thought a bit harder and it all clicked! :)

Terrible theme and even worse cluing. Not clever by half. 
10 themes down.

Sissy Hankshaw approves this puzzle.
Me, i'm a little disappointed that "a certain leviathan" was not FudgIE the Whale.
what a cool puzzle - it took a while to suss out the theme, but there was just enough breadcrumbs to get you there. no overwhelming trivia and a code that wanted to be solved. very fun!!!

Shocked at how long it took to figure out my mistake in the opposite of Me Too. I knew that area wasn't right because I didn't think there were any trees in the National Mall spelled ACtE.

Loved the revealer. I sat here moving my thumbs all around.

Fun puzzle. 26:44 unaided.  A bit fast for a Thursday, but not horribly so.

I'm glad I'm not the only one who had Not I at first.

That was the last to fall for me. Kept wondering what an Acte was.

26 down.  Evil.  Diabolical.  Who immediately got the right answer to 26D?  Not I.  Did you get tricked into entering what seemed to me to be the more obvious answer?  Me too.  I haven't read any comments yet.  Deb did not mention it, so I guess she did not think it tricky.  Maybe I am the only one.  

Not going to report my relative time.

Sorry if I missed it, but I didn‚Äôt see anyone else get thrown by the 5D [Common lunch box item] and 15A [Like sci-fi‚Äôs Jabba the Hutt] crossing. PNJ I thought. That lead to ONESE. Not knowing Jabba the Hutt‚Äôs exact origins led to Onese ancestry seeming to be perfectly reasonable. PNB then never crossed my mind.

Not to get too much into the (sea)weeds with NORI 
‚Äú I had trouble with 26 down‚Äù
‚ÄúMe too!‚Äù
‚ÄúNor I‚Äù ???
Who has devised a construct where it works as an opposite? Not I.

Thank you Deb for explaining the theme. I got it, but I didn‚Äôt get it, if you know what I mean. Some days I‚Äôm a bit thick-headed. Other days, I‚Äôm worse. LOL!

Have a good day all!
Solved it fine but still don't get the "theme" and don't really care. If it has to be explained, as many commenters note below, then it was not well executed.

Did you dislike this puzzle? NORI! With baseball on the brain right now (go M's), I thought for certain this was baseball themed for the first half. No tricks this Thursday, but still a treat. üëçüèºüëçüèº
Loved it! Thursdays are my favorite, and this one was particularly fun with a fresh think-outside-the-box trick. All thumbs up!
Thank you, Freddie, for a fun Thursday with such clever clues! Thanks, also, to you, Deb, for the cute visual of waking your pooch with your aha moment!
What a nice tune up for the weekend puzzles!

Why is 56D IMS?
Thanks

How about:

Clue: Two in
Answer: THISGUY

As in "What has two thumbs and likes crossword puzzles?" 

I know - don't quit your day job.
what on earth is klutzy all thumbs? what does that mean? is that a reference?

One (hopefully) last comment about opposites‚Äîthis came to mind when Barry said I was being too rigid in my definition. I was reminded of one of my favorite lines in Tom Stoppard‚Äôs ‚ÄúRosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead‚Äù:
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre actors. We‚Äôre the opposite of people!‚Äù
Cute and fun, but would have loved to have seen Siskel and Ebert used in one of the clues.
Oct. 9: 32 across?
This was hands down one of the most fun puzzles to solve ever.  Thank you!
I was SHER I had Two Up with NOTI. HODME a couple SODAS please. No ACTE!
The fill was pretty easy so I didn't get the theme until I checked the comments after I solved it. Clever!
Two thumbs up for today's theme! What a fun puzzle.
For 26D I had NOTI for way too long.  Killed my time today spending nearly 30 minutes flyspecking.
Great puzzle! Fun theme, very nice AHA payload! Great cluing throughout.
Was not thrilled by the clue and answer at 15A.
NORI (not NOtI) killed me.

Finished in half my Thursday time, and would have been a third if I didn't get stuck on Go oN instead of GRIN (ToNE looked fine, but I didn't know what a GoAM was).

Regardless, I thought I was hooped because I couldn't make sense of the themers. 2 up, 2 down, 1 out all sound like baseball terms, and the Yankees are (were) in the playoffs. But the moving around each other didn't make sense.

I had the same AHA! moment as Deb when I got the revealer through the crosses and that always brings a sigh of satisfaction.

Great fill. Love the throwbacks to ROLODEX and CD ROM (which makes me feel really old).

But mostly, GO BLUE JAYS!!!
I thought the same word couldn't appear in multiple answers. How come it's able to be in both 11-Down and 64-Across?
I love that ‚Äúperfect‚Äù worked as a clue for both AONE and HONE. I mean, I hated it in the moment, but how cleverly devious!

@Lisa
Ok, finally got the puzzle filled in correctly and still have ROAD‚Ä¶.

@Lisa

Could be 26D.  I had to correct a letter in that one.  ROAD is correct (column in wrong).

Lisa,

‚ÄúMe too‚Äù on NORI. Honestly this is a ln incorrect clue any way you slice it. If someone says ‚ÄúI am‚Ä¶‚Äù you might say ‚Äúme too‚Äù‚Äô or you could say ‚Äúnot I‚Äù. If you say ‚Äúnor I‚Äù the assumption is that the person said ‚ÄúI am not‚Ä¶‚Äù in which case you could say ‚ÄúNor I‚Äù  but you couldn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúMe too‚Äù. These are not opposites in any universe. But that‚Äôs my point, they have to be responses to different things so they can‚Äôt be opposites. It‚Äôs like saying apples and oranges are opposites‚Äîno,  they are just different.

@Jim

And if my other comment doesn‚Äôt convince you, how about this‚Äî they can actually mean the same thing!

I am not going to the store‚Äîme, too. (Clearly I also am not going to the store). 
I am not going to the store‚Äînor I. (Same meaning)
I am not going to budge on this one‚Ä¶

@SP Nope. Maybe ‚ÄúNeither do I‚Äù is more common than ‚ÄúMe neither,‚Äù but ‚ÄúMe too‚Äù as a reply to a negative statement is both ungrammatical and unconversational. What‚Äôs the unstated question in each of these verses? https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=UbeaLb4KvEE

Too bad for the relatively early exit for the Yankees.

Now, as a Minnesota fan, I am constitutionally unable to not smile when the Yankees finally go down for the year (when they do).

The reason is that Minnesota simply cannot beat the Yankees.  Not in the regular season, and especially not in the playoffs.

In the time since I relocated to Minnesota up until two seasons ago, Minnesota lost *18 playoff games in a row*.  

Eighteen.  In.  A.  Row.  

Smashes all existing playoff losing streaks.  Absolutely defied explanation.  The probabilities based on Win/Loss records would be in the one in many hundreds of thousands, if not millions.

And many of those loses were to the Yankees.

@Francis

It's amazing the differences in standards today. I was thinking about that at my salon appointment today and when I picked up Chipotle afterwards for dinner ...  in both cases, the people who helped me were all tattooed up and down all over the place... That's only what I could see. 

I don't have any tats, but I remember so clearly how adamant things were about guys with long hair and anyone with tats, weird piercings etc etc.  

My brother even recently told my niece that she wouldn't get a job if she did like pink highlights in her hair or something and I was like, that is just not true anymore... You want a couple pink streaks in your hair, do it! People express themselves in different ways and, well that's not exactly me,  I'm glad that things are looser now. 

I know that's not exactly what you're saying, but it seems related. People can say what they will about the younger generations, but I think in so many ways they are doing great! And I am here for it!! I truly hope my niece gets some highlights in her hair but her parents, you know my brother and sister-in-law, along with the rest of my family are very conservative and so I'm not sure. Occasionally I think she might fall far from the tree like I did and my aunt did, but time will tell

I am happy that you feel free to wear your hair as you please now!!

@HeathieJ

I can't quite get used to tattoos, especially elaborate ones, or piercings in anything other than an ear.

But I recognize in myself the same sort of reaction my parents' generation had to long hair at the time.  I mean, it was really a big deal!  

I wrote a Letter to the Editor (remember those?) talking about having long hair.  I actually got a call from a lady the next day and she argued with me for at least a half hour about why I just had to have long hair.

(Boy, those were the days considering what were screaming at each other about now, huh?)

So even though a couple of my kids have tattoos, I try not to let them see my gut level disapproval.  They're entitled to their own culture.
